4.9.20  8:03 am   hi, you probably wont see this but i just wanted to say, i watched some of your reality vids and its inspiring to me that you struggled with things im currently struggling with, and you managed to make a lot of cool and funny things. its also given me ideas how to manage my own workflow. so thank you for doing what you been doing, and im excited for what you have in store for the future <3

     holy blanket policy statement, you are very friendly

4.9.20  7:02 am   Okay, so, the answer about the stacked same exact voicings per octave got me thinking: I can see how this technique could be useless in the context of a chord voicing spread throughout more than the space of an octave (at least), but what if I want to achieve some reinforcement over a certain voicing much like when some harmonic distortion is added to enrich or fatten a sound? Some mud may be necessary to be cut via EQing (if used in the wrong areas), but it seems like a valid production technique when trying to add some density while maintaining the harmonic colour, if you will.

     absolutely, but it will NOT work if you use the exact same notes in a different octave. what you are trying to achieve will be achieved by using different notes, and i would be delighted to tell you which

     Also, may add some stereo dimension when taking panning into account. What do you say? 

     as octaves go up and down, you need different amounts of notes to re enforce the same exact sound you had. using the same exact 'notes' in different octaves will make the sound different, in fact dare i say will weaken it and add an 'ick' factor. if you tell me any notes and exactly what octave they are in, i will give you my best suggestion(s) of how to re enforce it while keeping the exact same flavor. you can even tell me how much distortion you happen to have on it. i promise you the answer will never be the exact same notes in a different octave..... that's just not what's gonna re enforce the original sound. the exception to this is if you started with only 1 note

4.9.20  3:46 am   I have too much questions that can't be answered and then creates more questions. Can you help me?

     try going back the other way - discover the questions that led to those first questions. i think you will find if you go in that direction, there will be fewer questions there, and if you keep going that way you can sometimes actually get it back to the original question. and then the answers explode back outward, through all the tree branches easily. it's really spectacular

4.9.20  12:51 am   What's the deal with Popcorn?

      the corn is filled with fluff, and when the fluff gets too hot it pops out of the corn. hot fluff. science is working very hard to figure out how to produce the hot fluff without the corn, but the problem is, even after it's popped, the corn serves a purpose: it keeps the fluff from expanding even more. without the corn, the fluff would actually keep expanding and engulf the entire universe

4.9.20  12:08 am   I can't get in the studio with my band, so I'm sending them the individual instrument parts to record themselves, in their homes. Guitar and bass and keys can record through an interface, but I don't know how to get quality audio from the acoustic instruments. (For most of them, the only mic around is in their phone) How can we get clean takes from that kind of limited setup?

     what stands out more to me in this situation are not concerns of acoustics, but concerns of how the band plays together (or, how to effectively simulate the phenomenon of the band actually playing together). one thing i will suggest is to do the drums first, so everyone else can hear the drums. that's just for the sake of the chemistry and the quality of everyone playing together. Actually, what i would really recommend is, after doing the drums first, send it to the chordal instruments, then send it to vocals, then send it to bass, then send it back to the drummer with drums muted and a very strong click (oh i forgot to mention you absolutely must have the click in there from the start), then send it back to the chordal instrument(s) and have them re-do that, with the new drums included, then maybe send it to bass to have that redone, then back to vocals, keep going around like this and have the people re-do their parts each time, because each time it gets closer and closer to creating the illusion of people actually playing together, because now they are hearing each other... even better, they are hearing each other do what they did while hearing each other. but i just realized you probably already knew all this. but as far as acoustics, just remember that some people spend millions of dollars on ways to try to deliberately simulate bad acoustics. hope that helps
